In 1983: then-Senator Biden voted in favor of legislation that allowed up to 50% of Social Security benefits to be added to taxable income if the taxpayer's total income exceeded certain thresholds. This legislation was intended to shore up Social Security and had bipartisan support.
In 1993: the Senate, including Biden, passed President Bill Clinton's deficit reduction plan, which required recipients with certain incomes to pay taxes on 85% of their Social Security benefits.
The claim that Biden was the deciding vo: to 85% in 1993 is not accurate. While Biden did vote for those tax changes, he was not the sole deciding vote.
